Differentially Private AUC Computation
in Vertical Federated Learning

Jiankai Sun &Xin Yang &Yuanshun Yao &Junyuan Xie &Di Wu &Chong Wang Bytedance Inc. Corresponds to {jiankai.sun, chong.wang}@bytedance.com
Abstract

Federated learning has gained great attention recently as a privacy-enhancing tool to jointly train a machine learning model by multiple parties. As a sub-category, vertical federated learning (vFL) focuses on the scenario where features and labels are split into different parties. The prior work on vFL has mostly studied how to protect label privacy during model training. However, model evaluation in vFL might also lead to potential leakage of private label information. One mitigation strategy is to apply label differential privacy (DP) but it gives bad estimations of the true (non-private) metrics. In this work, we propose two evaluation algorithms that can more accurately compute the widely used AUC (area under curve) metric when using label DP in vFL. Through extensive experiments, we show our algorithms can achieve more accurate AUCs compared to the baselines.

1 Introduction

With increasing concerns over data privacy in machine learning, regulations like CCPA111California Consumer Privacy Act, HIPAA222Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, and GDPR333General Data Protection Regulation, European Union have been introduced to regulate how data can be transmitted and used. To address privacy concerns, federated learning [19, 14, 31, 11] has become an increasingly popular tool to enhance privacy by allowing training models without directly sharing their data. As a specific type of federated learning, vertical federated learning (vFL) [30, 12, 28] focuses on the application when the data is separately owned by multiple parties and each party holds either features or labels of the same data subjects. For example, in online advertising [17, 26], advertisers and the advertising platform (e.g. Google, Meta, and TikTok) can jointly train a model to predict the conversion rate (CVR) of an ad impression. In vFL protocol, the model is split layerwise and disjointly owned by advertisers and the platform, and the training and test are done by exchanging backward gradients and forward embeddings rather than the raw data. Therefore private information like user information (i.e. features) remains on the platform while the conversion events (i.e. labels) are kept to advertisers. We refer to the platform which only owns raw features and is in charge of the communication as the server, and the individual parties (advertisers) which own private labels as clients.

Despite the practical usefulness of vFL, researchers have shown that vFL can still leak data information indirectly. For example, Li et al [17] demonstrate that the gradient updates between the server and client can leak label information. However, the prior work on vFL privacy mostly focuses on the model training and there can also be privacy leaked from model evaluation. Specifically, the private label information owned by clients can be leaked to the server when computing evaluation metrics. For example, Stoddard el al. [24] show that the server can simply guess the labels, plot the ROC curve, and compare it with the given ROC curve.

In this work, we focus on protecting label privacy when multiple parties jointly evaluate the trained vFL model. Specifically, we want to protect privacy when computing AUC. AUC is a widely used and standard metric; therefore it is a must when evaluating models. However, computing AUC in vFL while protecting label information is challenging because AUC requires sorting the testing samples by predicted score globally (i.e. from all clients) which is a procedure more complicated than other simpler metrics (e.g. test loss or accuracy). For example, the server can compute global test loss easily by simply asking all clients to send their local loss and then compute the global test loss as the weighted sum (weighted by the number of local samples). However, simply aggregating local AUC does not lead to the correct global AUC because the overall AUC requires global ranking.

To address the challenge, we leverage probabilistic interpretation of AUC related to Mann-Whitney U statistics [22, 4]. We view AUC as the probability of correct ranking of a random positive-negative pair and we can avoid requiring clients to send their labels to the server. Our goal is to achieve label differential privacy [10] since the class label is often the most sensitive information in a prediction task. To this end, we propose two DP mechanisms. The first leverages randomized response to flip local labels in the clients, and then we debias the AUC computed with flipped labels. The second approach adopts the Laplace mechanism (Gaussian mechanism is applicable too) to add noise to the shared intermediate information between the server and clients to calculate the AUC. We conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed approaches.

2 Preliminaries

We start with introducing some background knowledge of our work.

2.1 Vertical Federated Learning

Training. The training of vFL includes forward pass and backward gradients computation. During the forward pass, the party without labels (server) sends the intermediate layer (cut layer) outputs rather than the raw data to the party with labels (clients), and the clients completes the rest of the forward computation to obtain the training loss. In the backward phase, to compute the gradients w.r.t model parameters, the client performs backpropagation from its training loss, computes its own parameters’ gradients, and updates its own model. The client also computes the gradients w.r.t cut layer outputs and sends it to the server, and then server uses the chain rule to compute gradients of its model parameters, and update its model.

Inference. During inference time, the server computes the cut layer embedding and sends it to the clients. Clients then execute the rest of forward computation to compute the prediction probability.

We focus on the setting of multi-party vFL which contains one server and multi clients. The labels are distributed in multi clients and our proposed approaches can compute the evaluation metric AUC with label differential privacy.

2.2 Label Differential Privacy

In our work, we focus on protecting the privacy of label information. Following  [10], we define label differential privacy as the following:

Definition 2.1 (Label Differential Privacy).

Let ϵ,δ∈ℝ≥0italic-ϵ𝛿subscriptℝabsent0\epsilon,\delta\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, a randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-label differentially private (i.e. (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LabelDP), if for any of two neighboring training datasets D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} that differ in the label of a single example, and for any subset S𝑆S of possible output of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, we have

Pr⁡[ℳ​(D)∈S]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[ℳ​(D′)∈S]+δ.Prℳ𝐷𝑆⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrℳsuperscript𝐷′𝑆𝛿\displaystyle\Pr[\mathcal{M}(D)\in S]\leq e^{\epsilon}\cdot\Pr[\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in S]+\delta.

If δ=0𝛿0\delta=0, then M𝑀M is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-label differentially private (i.e. ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LabelDP).

Our proposed approaches also shares the same setting with local DP  [7, 9, 16, 2] which assumes that the data collector (server in our paper) is untrusted. Following the same setting with local DP, in our proposed approaches, each client locally perturbs their private labels with a DP mechanism and transfers the perturbed version to the server. After receiving all clients’ perturbed data, the server calculates the statistics and publishes the result of AUC. We define local DP as the following:

Definition 2.2 (Local Differential Privacy).

Let ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 and 1>δ≥01𝛿01>\delta\geq 0, a randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-local differentially private (i.e. (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LocalDP), if and only if for any pair of input values v𝑣v and v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime} in domain D𝐷D, and for any subset S𝑆S of possible output of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, we have

Pr⁡[ℳ​(v)∈S]≤eϵ⋅Pr⁡[ℳ​(v′)∈S]+δ.Prℳ𝑣𝑆⋅superscript𝑒italic-ϵPrℳsuperscript𝑣′𝑆𝛿\displaystyle\Pr[\mathcal{M}(v)\in S]\leq e^{\epsilon}\cdot\Pr[\mathcal{M}(v^{\prime})\in S]+\delta.

If δ=0𝛿0\delta=0, then M𝑀M is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-local differentially private (i.e. ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LocalDP).

Definition 2.3 (Sensitivity).

Let d𝑑d be a positive integer, 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} be a collection of datasets, and f:𝒟→ℛd:𝑓→𝒟superscriptℛ𝑑f:\mathcal{D}\rightarrow\mathcal{R}^{d} be a function. The sensitivity of a function, denoted Δ​fΔ𝑓\Delta f, is defined by Δ​f=m​a​x​‖f​(D)−f​(D′)‖pΔ𝑓𝑚𝑎𝑥subscriptnorm𝑓𝐷𝑓superscript𝐷′𝑝\Delta f=max||f(D)-f(D^{\prime})||_{p} where the maximum is over all pairs of datasets D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} differing in at most one element and ||⋅||p||\cdot||_{p} denotes the lpsubscript𝑙𝑝l_{p} norm.

Lemma 1 (Laplace Mechanism).

Laplace mechanism preserves (ϵ,0)italic-ϵ0(\epsilon,0)-differential privacy if the random noise is drawn from L​a​p​(Δ/ϵ)𝐿𝑎𝑝Δitalic-ϵLap(\Delta/\epsilon).

2.3 ROC Curve and AUC

In a binary classification problem, given a threshold θ𝜃\theta, a predicted score sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} is predicted to be 111 if si≥θsubscript𝑠𝑖𝜃s_{i}\geq\theta. Given the ground-truth label and the predicted label (at a given threshold θ𝜃\theta), we can compute True Positive Rate (TPR) and False Positive Rate (FPR). TPR (i.e. recall) is defined as T​P​R​(θ)=T​P​(θ)T​P​(θ)+F​N​(θ)𝑇𝑃𝑅𝜃𝑇𝑃𝜃𝑇𝑃𝜃𝐹𝑁𝜃TPR(\theta)=\frac{TP(\theta)}{TP(\theta)+FN(\theta)} and False Positive Rate (FPR) is defined as F​P​R​(θ)=F​P​(θ)F​P​(θ)+T​N​(θ)𝐹𝑃𝑅𝜃𝐹𝑃𝜃𝐹𝑃𝜃𝑇𝑁𝜃FPR(\theta)=\frac{FP(\theta)}{FP(\theta)+TN(\theta)}. Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve plots TPR (x-axis) vs. FPR (y-axis) over all possible thresholds θ𝜃\theta, and AUC is the area under the ROC curve. A perfect classifier has AUC 1.01.01.0 while a classifier giving random predictions has AUC 0.50.50.5.

Privacy Leakage in AUC. Researchers have shown AUC computation can cause privacy leakage. Matthews and Harel [18] demonstrate that by using a subset of the ground-truth data and the computed ROC curve, the data underlying the ROC curve can be reproduced accurately. Stoddard el al. [24] show that an attacker can determine the unknown label by simply enumerating over all labels, guessing the labels, and then checking which guesses lead to the given ROC curve. They propose a differentially private ROC curve computation algorithm that adds DP noise to TPRs and FPRs.

2.4 Probabilistic Interpretation of AUC

Area under ROC curve (AUC) can be related to Mann-Whitney U statistics  [22, 4] by viewing it as the probability of correct ranking of a random positive-negative pair. Suppose we have M𝑀M samples with P𝑃P positive and N𝑁N negative samples, where M=P+N𝑀𝑃𝑁M=P+N. Given a classifier ℱℱ\mathcal{F} that outputs a prediction score sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} for each sample with index i𝑖i from 1 to M𝑀M. To compute AUC, we first sort all samples based on their prediction scores with an increasing order, i.e. each predicted score sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} is assigned a rank risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} where ri=0subscript𝑟𝑖0r_{i}=0 indicates sample with index i𝑖i has the lowest prediction score sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} and where ri=M−1subscript𝑟𝑖𝑀1r_{i}=M-1 indicates the highest. Then AUC can be computed as the following:

AUC=∑i=1Mri⋅yi−P​(P−1)2P​NAUCsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀⋅subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑃𝑃12𝑃𝑁\text{AUC}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}r_{i}\cdot y_{i}-\frac{P(P-1)}{2}}{PN} (1)

where yi∈{0,1}subscript𝑦𝑖01y_{i}\in\{0,1\} is the ground-truth label for sample i𝑖i. We include more details in Section  H of the Appendix.

3 Threat Model

We formally define our scenario. In our vFL setting, there are multiple label parties (i.e. clients) that own private labels (i.e. Y)444they can also own some features and there is a central non-label party (i.e. server) that owns features and is responsible for computing global AUC from all clients. The model (early layers) owned by the server is shared by all clients, and each client owns its individual model (late layers) trained on their own private data. Before the training starts, the server and each client split their data into training and test set. The model is trained using the normal vFL protocol.

Our work focuses on the evaluation time and the goal of the server is to compute global AUC without letting clients directly share their private test data. In other words, clients cannot directly send the test data (i.e. private labels) to the server for it to compute AUC. Specifically, we are interested in protecting label information and therefore it is required that the exchanged information between client and server excludes the ground-truth test labels (Y).

Note that the exchanged information might contain some indirect information that can be used by the server to infer clients’ test labels (Y), e.g. the predicted score f​(X)𝑓𝑋f(X), which we assume to be considered non-sensitive by nature of the task. For example, in online advertising, clients (i.e. advertisers) have to send the predicted scores, i.e. predicted conversion rate (CVR), to the server (i.e. advertising platforms like Google, Meta, or Tiktok) so that the server can compute the bid price [23]. In this case, the predicted scores have to be shared with the server in order to perform the task, and clients have already agreed to share them before participating in vFL. We include more discussion on the privacy sensitivity of predicted scores in Section R in the Appendix.

4 Proposed Algorithm 1: Randomized Response Mechanism

We introduce our first algorithm to compute AUC when applying label DP to vFL for evaluation. The algorithm is based on randomized response [29] and we name it as FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}. We include the workflow in Figure  2 in the Appendix. We now explain the algorithm step by step.

4.1 Step 1: Clients Flip Their Local Labels

Randomized response (RR) is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LabelDP and works as following: let ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon be a parameter and let y∈{0,1}𝑦01y\in\{0,1\} be the true label. Given a query of y𝑦y, RR will respond with a random draw y~~𝑦\tilde{y} from the following probability distribution:

Pr⁡[y~=y^]={eϵ1+eϵfor y=y^,11+eϵotherwise.Pr~𝑦^𝑦casessuperscript𝑒italic-ϵ1superscript𝑒italic-ϵfor y=y^,11superscript𝑒italic-ϵotherwise.\Pr[\tilde{y}=\hat{y}]=\begin{cases}\frac{e^{\epsilon}}{1+e^{\epsilon}}&\text{for $y=\hat{y}$,}\\ \frac{1}{1+e^{\epsilon}}&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases} (2)

Clients can leverage randomized response (Algorithm  1 in the Appendix) to flip their owning labels as a preprocessing step before computing the AUC. It’s worth mentioning that all labels are only flipped once and the generated noisy labels can then be used for further evaluations multi-times.

4.2 Step 2: Server Computes AUC from Flipped Labels

We now talk about how to compute the AUC with the flipped labels (detailed description can be seen in Algorithm  2 in the Appendix). Since the corresponding AUC is computed with flipped labels, we denote this AUC as noisy AUC: AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}}. It has four steps:

  1. 1.

    Clients Execute. Suppose we have K𝐾K clients. Each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} computes the prediction scores sk=f​(Xk)subscript𝑠𝑘𝑓subscript𝑋𝑘s_{k}=f(X_{k}) for all its owning data points and sends shuffled sksuperscript𝑠𝑘s^{k} to the server.

  2. 2.

    Server Executes. The server aggregates all the prediction scores and sort them in an increasing order. Each prediction score siksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑘s_{i}^{k} (i∈[1,M]𝑖1𝑀i\in[1,M]) will be assigned a ranking order riksuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘r_{i}^{k}. The instance with the highest order will be assigned r=M−1𝑟𝑀1r=M-1, and the second highest one will be assigned M−2𝑀2M-2 and so on. The smallest ranking score is r=0𝑟0r=0. The server sends each ranking order riksuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘r_{i}^{k} back to the corresponding client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} which owns siksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑘s_{i}^{k}.

  3. 3.

    Clients Execute. Each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} then aggregates all its received ranking orders with the noisy label generated in Algorithm  1. The corresponding result is localSumk=∑i|Yk|rik⋅yi′subscriptlocalSum𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑌𝑘⋅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖′\text{localSum}_{k}=\sum_{i}^{|{Y_{k}}|}r_{i}^{k}\cdot{y_{i}}^{\prime}, where yi′superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖′y_{i}^{\prime} is the flipped version of ground-truth label yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}. The client also computes its number of noisy positive (localP) and negative (localN) instances respectively. Here localP=∑i|Yk|yi′localPsuperscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖′\text{localP}=\sum_{i}^{|{Y_{k}}|}{y_{i}}^{\prime} and localN=∑i|Yk|(1−yi′)localNsuperscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑌𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖′\text{localN}=\sum_{i}^{|{Y_{k}}|}(1-{y_{i}}^{\prime}). Each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} sends its localSumksubscriptlocalSum𝑘\text{localSum}_{k}, localPksubscriptlocalP𝑘\text{localP}_{k}, and localNksubscriptlocalN𝑘\text{localN}_{k} to the server.

  4. 4.

    Server Executes. After receiving all clients’ localSum, localP and localN, the server aggregates them to get the corresponding global values. Here globalSum=∑kKlocalSumkglobalSumsuperscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾subscriptlocalSum𝑘\text{globalSum}=\sum_{k}^{K}\text{localSum}_{k}, P¯=∑kKlocalPk¯𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾subscriptlocalP𝑘\bar{P}=\sum_{k}^{K}\text{localP}_{k}, and N¯=∑kKlocalNk¯𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾subscriptlocalN𝑘\bar{N}=\sum_{k}^{K}\text{localN}_{k}. The server then leverages equation  (1) to compute the AUC. We then get the corresponding noisy AUC: AUCDnoisy=globalSum−P¯​(P¯−1)/2P¯​N¯superscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisyglobalSum¯𝑃¯𝑃12¯𝑃¯𝑁\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}}=\frac{{\text{globalSum}-{\bar{P}(\bar{P}-1)}/{2}}}{{\bar{P}\bar{N}}}.

It’s possible that the clients can send their flipped labels and corresponding prediction scores to the server directly and the server then computes AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}} in a centralized way. Both methods will get the same value of the noisy AUC. To be consistent with our other mechanisms, we instead introduce the one with four steps here.

4.3 Step 3: Server Debiases AUC

Section  4.2 shows how the server compute AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}} with using clients’ local flipped labels. Empirically, the noisy AUC can be useless with a small privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon (see experimental results in Table  3 in the Appendix). In this section, we show how to covert AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}} to the final AUC that we are interested in and we name it as AUCDcleansuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷clean\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{clean}}}. AUCDcleansuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷clean\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{clean}}} is a more accurate estimation of the ground-truth AUC than AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}}.

[21] proposed to learn from noisy binary labels via class-probability estimation. They draw (X,Y)∼Dsimilar-to𝑋𝑌𝐷(X,Y)\sim D. The instance X𝑋X is unchanged: however, the label is altered such that positive samples have labels flipped with probability ρ+subscript𝜌\rho_{+}, while negative samples have labels flipped with probability ρ−subscript𝜌\rho_{-}. We note the AUC computed based on the ground-truth labels as AUCDcleansuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷clean\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{clean}}}. [21] proved the following relation between AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}} and AUCDcleansuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷clean\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{clean}}}:

AUCDclean=AUCDnoisy−α+β21−α−βsuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷cleansuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy𝛼𝛽21𝛼𝛽\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{clean}}}=\frac{\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}}-\frac{\alpha+\beta}{2}}{1-\alpha-\beta} (3)

where

α=(1−π)​ρ−π​(1−ρ+)+(1−π)​ρ−,β=π​ρ+π​ρ++(1−π)​(1−ρ−)formulae-sequence𝛼1𝜋subscript𝜌𝜋1subscript𝜌1𝜋subscript𝜌𝛽𝜋subscript𝜌𝜋subscript𝜌1𝜋1subscript𝜌\alpha=\frac{(1-\pi)\rho_{-}}{\pi(1-\rho_{+})+(1-\pi)\rho_{-}},\quad\beta=\frac{\pi\rho_{+}}{\pi\rho_{+}+(1-\pi)(1-\rho_{-})} (4)

Here π=PD​(Y=1)𝜋subscript𝑃𝐷𝑌1\pi=P_{D}(Y=1) is the positive ratio (base rate) in the clean data D𝐷D. π𝜋\pi is unknown to the server. However, the server can estimate π𝜋\pi from the known information of the noisy data D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}. Suppose we observe M¯¯𝑀\bar{M} positive examples and N¯¯𝑁\bar{N} negative examples in the noisy data D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}. We then estimate π𝜋\pi as π′=P′P′+N′superscript𝜋′superscript𝑃′superscript𝑃′superscript𝑁′\pi^{\prime}=\frac{P^{\prime}}{P^{\prime}+N^{\prime}} where P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} and N′superscript𝑁′N^{\prime} are estimated positive and negative numbers in the clean data D𝐷D. And they can be estimated as P′=P¯​(1−ρ−)−N¯​ρ−1−ρ+−ρ−superscript𝑃′¯𝑃1subscript𝜌¯𝑁subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌subscript𝜌P^{\prime}=\frac{\bar{P}(1-\rho_{-})-\bar{N}\rho_{-}}{1-\rho_{+}-\rho_{-}}, and N′=P¯+N¯−P′superscript𝑁′¯𝑃¯𝑁superscript𝑃′\quad N^{\prime}=\bar{P}+\bar{N}-P^{\prime}. More details can be in Section  P of the Appendix.

After we get get AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}} and π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}, we can leverage equation  (4) to compute α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta, and then use equation  3 to get the AUCDcleansuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷clean\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{clean}}} that we are interested in. Algorithm  3 in the Appendix shows how the server compute AUCDcleansuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷clean\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{clean}}} from AUCDnoisysuperscriptAUCsubscript𝐷noisy\text{AUC}^{D_{\text{noisy}}}, P¯¯𝑃\bar{P}, N¯¯𝑁\bar{N}, and Label DP budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

Privacy and Utility Analysis. Our proposed approach is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LabelDP since all of operations are on the noisy labels flipped by randomized response which is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-LabelDP. We include the utility (variance of computed AUC) analysis in Section I of the Appendix.

5 Proposed Algorithm 2: Laplace and Gaussian Mechanism

In this section, we introduce how to compute the AUC with label differential privacy by leveraging Laplace and Gaussian mechanism. Here we use Laplace mechanism as an example. Other settings for the Gaussian mechanism will be the same.

5.1 Overall Workflow

The workflow of this method is as shown in Figure  3 in the appendix and the detailed Algorithm is shown in Algorithm  4 in the Appendix. The algorithm has four steps (the first two steps are the same as FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}):

  1. 1.

    Clients Execute. Each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} computes the prediction scores sk=f​(Xk)subscript𝑠𝑘𝑓subscript𝑋𝑘s_{k}=f(X_{k}) for all its owning data points and sends shuffled sksuperscript𝑠𝑘s^{k} to the server.

  2. 2.

    Server Executes. The server aggregates all the prediction scores and sort them in an increasing order. Each prediction score siksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑘s_{i}^{k} (i∈[1,M]𝑖1𝑀i\in[1,M]) will be assigned a ranking order riksuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘r_{i}^{k}. The server sends each ranking order riksuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘r_{i}^{k} back to the corresponding client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} which owns siksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑘s_{i}^{k}.

  3. 3.

    Clients Execute. Each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} then aggregates all its received ranking orders with its label. The corresponding result is localSumk=∑i|Yk|rik⋅yisubscriptlocalSum𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑌𝑘⋅superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘subscript𝑦𝑖\text{localSum}_{k}=\sum_{i}^{|{Y_{k}}|}r_{i}^{k}\cdot{y_{i}}, where yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the ground-truth label. The client also computes its number of positive (localP) and negative (localN) instances respectively. Here localP=∑i|Yk|yilocalPsuperscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑌𝑘subscript𝑦𝑖\text{localP}=\sum_{i}^{|{Y_{k}}|}{y_{i}} and localN=∑i|Yk|(1−yi)localNsuperscriptsubscript𝑖subscript𝑌𝑘1subscript𝑦𝑖\text{localN}=\sum_{i}^{|{Y_{k}}|}(1-{y_{i}}). Each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} adds noise to localSumksubscriptlocalSum𝑘\text{localSum}_{k} and localPksubscriptlocalP𝑘\text{localP}_{k} to get localSumk′superscriptsubscriptlocalSum𝑘′\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime} and localPk′superscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime} respectively. The client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} sends localSumk′superscriptsubscriptlocalSum𝑘′\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}, localPk′superscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}, and localNk′superscriptsubscriptlocalN𝑘′\text{localN}_{k}^{\prime} (localNk′=|Yk|−localPk′superscriptsubscriptlocalN𝑘′subscript𝑌𝑘superscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′\text{localN}_{k}^{\prime}=|Y_{k}|-\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}) to the server. We talk about how to add noises to these local statistics in Section  5.2.

  4. 4.

    Server Executes. After receiving all clients’ localSum′superscriptlocalSum′\text{localSum}^{\prime}, localP′superscriptlocalP′\text{localP}^{\prime} and localN′superscriptlocalN′\text{localN}^{\prime}, the server aggregates them to get the corresponding global values. Here globalSum=∑kKlocalSumk′globalSumsuperscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscriptlocalSum𝑘′\text{globalSum}=\sum_{k}^{K}\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}, P¯=∑kKlocalPk′¯𝑃superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′\bar{P}=\sum_{k}^{K}\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}, and N¯=∑kKlocalNk′¯𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscriptlocalN𝑘′\bar{N}=\sum_{k}^{K}\text{localN}_{k}^{\prime}. The server then leverages equation  (1) to compute the AUC. The final AUC is: AUC=globalSum−P¯​(P¯−1)/2P¯​N¯AUCglobalSum¯𝑃¯𝑃12¯𝑃¯𝑁\text{AUC}=\frac{{\text{globalSum}-{\bar{P}(\bar{P}-1)}/{2}}}{{\bar{P}\bar{N}}}.

5.2 Adding Noise to Local Statistics

We explain in details how to perturb localSum and localP for each client in the algorithm. Both Gaussian and Laplace mechanisms can be leveraged to generate the corresponding DP noise. Without loss of generality, we use Laplace as an example. Laplace mechanism preserves (ϵ,0)italic-ϵ0(\epsilon,0)-differential privacy if the random noise is drawn from L​a​p​(Δ/ϵ)𝐿𝑎𝑝Δitalic-ϵLap(\Delta/\epsilon) where ΔΔ\Delta is the l1subscript𝑙1l_{1} sensitivity. We name this method as FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}. The noise is added as the following:

  1. 1.

    Adding noise to localSum: Each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} decides its own sensitivity by selecting its maximum ranking order as ΔlocalSumk=maxi∈[1,|Yk|]⁡(rik)subscriptΔsuperscriptlocalSum𝑘subscript𝑖1subscript𝑌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘\Delta_{\text{localSum}^{k}}=\max_{i\in[1,|Y_{k}|]}(r_{i}^{k}). Given a privacy budget ϵl​o​c​a​l​S​u​msubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑆𝑢𝑚\epsilon_{localSum}, client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} draws the random noise from Lap​(ΔlocalSumk/ϵl​o​c​a​l​S​u​m)LapsubscriptΔsuperscriptlocalSum𝑘subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑆𝑢𝑚\textsf{Lap}(\Delta_{\text{localSum}^{k}}/\epsilon_{localSum}).

  2. 2.

    Adding noise to localP: Each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} sets ΔlocalPk=1subscriptΔsuperscriptlocalP𝑘1\Delta_{\text{localP}^{k}}=1. Given a privacy budget ϵl​o​c​a​l​Psubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑃\epsilon_{localP}, client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} draws the random noise from Lap​(1/ϵl​o​c​a​l​P)Lap1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑃\textsf{Lap}(1/\epsilon_{localP}).

Privacy Analysis. The total privacy budget ϵ=ϵl​o​c​a​l​S​u​m+ϵl​o​c​a​l​Pitalic-ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑆𝑢𝑚subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑃\epsilon=\epsilon_{localSum}+\epsilon_{localP}. We use a parameter α𝛼\alpha to control the budget allocation: ϵl​o​c​a​l​S​u​m=α​ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑆𝑢𝑚𝛼italic-ϵ\epsilon_{localSum}=\alpha\epsilon and ϵl​o​c​a​l​P=(1−α)​ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑃1𝛼italic-ϵ\epsilon_{localP}=(1-\alpha)\epsilon. Next we explain a a better allocation than using α𝛼\alpha.

5.3 Adaptive Allocation of DP Budget

Finding α𝛼\alpha that achieves a good tradeoff between utility and privacy can be difficult and would require many trials and errors if using cross validation. Therefore we propose an algorithm that automatically determines the allocation of the DP budget adaptively on each client.

Our inspiration comes from the special case where each client only owns 1 sample, i.e., |Yk|=1subscript𝑌𝑘1|Y_{k}|=1 for each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k}. In this case, it turns out that localSumk=rk⋅localPksubscriptlocalSum𝑘⋅superscript𝑟𝑘subscriptlocalP𝑘\text{localSum}_{k}=r^{k}\cdot\text{localP}_{k}. Since rksuperscript𝑟𝑘r^{k} is public, we do not need to generate two independent random variables; we can sample s∼𝖫𝖺𝗉​(1/ϵ)similar-to𝑠𝖫𝖺𝗉1italic-ϵs\sim\mathsf{Lap}(1/\epsilon), and report localPk′:=localPk+sassignsuperscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′subscriptlocalP𝑘𝑠\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}:=\text{localP}_{k}+s and localSumk′:=rk⋅localPk′assignsuperscriptsubscriptlocalSum𝑘′⋅superscript𝑟𝑘superscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}:=r^{k}\cdot\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}.

The above example shows that when localSumksubscriptlocalSum𝑘\text{localSum}_{k} and localPksubscriptlocalP𝑘\text{localP}_{k} are highly correlated, then the privacy budget can be allocated more efficiently. Based on this observation, we can analyze the general case. Fix the client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k}. Let 𝐲:=(y1,⋯,y|Yk|)∈{0,1}|Yk|assign𝐲subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝑦subscript𝑌𝑘superscript01subscript𝑌𝑘\mathbf{y}:=(y_{1},\cdots,y_{|Y_{k}|})\in\{0,1\}^{|Y_{k}|} be the labels held by Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k}, and 𝐫:=(r1k,⋯,r|Yk|k)∈ℤ|Yk|assign𝐫superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑘⋯superscriptsubscript𝑟subscript𝑌𝑘𝑘superscriptℤsubscript𝑌𝑘\mathbf{r}:=(r_{1}^{k},\cdots,r_{|Y_{k}|}^{k})\in\mathbb{Z}^{|Y_{k}|} be their rankings. Then we have localPk=⟨𝐮,𝐲⟩subscriptlocalP𝑘𝐮𝐲\text{localP}_{k}=\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{y}\rangle and localSumk=⟨𝐫,𝐲⟩subscriptlocalSum𝑘𝐫𝐲\text{localSum}_{k}=\langle\mathbf{r},\mathbf{y}\rangle, where 𝐮:=(1,1,⋯,1)assign𝐮11⋯1\mathbf{u}:=(1,1,\cdots,1) is the all-one vector.

When 𝐮𝐮\mathbf{u} and 𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r} are parallel, namely 𝐫=r⋅𝐮𝐫⋅𝑟𝐮\mathbf{r}=r\cdot\mathbf{u} for some r∈ℝ𝑟ℝr\in\mathbb{R}, we can still allocate all the budget on localPk′superscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}, and report localSumk′=r⋅localPk′superscriptsubscriptlocalSum𝑘′⋅𝑟superscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}=r\cdot\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}. Otherwise, we can decompose 𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r} into two orthogonal components: we can write 𝐫:=𝐮′+𝐯′assign𝐫superscript𝐮′superscript𝐯′\mathbf{r}:=\mathbf{u}^{\prime}+\mathbf{v}^{\prime} where 𝐮′∥𝐮conditionalsuperscript𝐮′𝐮\mathbf{u}^{\prime}\parallel\mathbf{u} and 𝐮′⟂𝐯′perpendicular-tosuperscript𝐮′superscript𝐯′\mathbf{u}^{\prime}\perp\mathbf{v^{\prime}}. Then we have

localSumk=⟨𝐫,𝐲⟩=⟨𝐮′,𝐲⟩+⟨𝐯′,𝐲⟩.subscriptlocalSum𝑘𝐫𝐲superscript𝐮′𝐲superscript𝐯′𝐲\displaystyle\text{localSum}_{k}=\langle\mathbf{r},\mathbf{y}\rangle=\langle\mathbf{u^{\prime}},\mathbf{y}\rangle+\langle\mathbf{v^{\prime}},\mathbf{y}\rangle.

In order to make (localPk,localSumk)subscriptlocalP𝑘subscriptlocalSum𝑘(\text{localP}_{k},\text{localSum}_{k}) ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP, by the post-processing property of differential privacy, it is sufficient to have (⟨𝐮′,y⟩,⟨𝐯′,y⟩)superscript𝐮′𝑦superscript𝐯′𝑦(\langle\mathbf{u}^{\prime},y\rangle,\langle\mathbf{v}^{\prime},y\rangle) to be ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP. We can use a parameter β𝛽\beta to control the budget allocation so that ⟨𝐮′,y⟩superscript𝐮′𝑦\langle\mathbf{u}^{\prime},y\rangle achieves β​ϵ𝛽italic-ϵ\beta\epsilon-DP and ⟨𝐯′,y⟩superscript𝐯′𝑦\langle\mathbf{v}^{\prime},y\rangle achieves (1−β)​ϵ1𝛽italic-ϵ(1-\beta)\epsilon-DP. If we use Laplace mechanism, this means we sample s1∼𝖫𝖺𝗉​(1/(β​ϵ))similar-tosubscript𝑠1𝖫𝖺𝗉1𝛽italic-ϵs_{1}\sim\mathsf{Lap}(1/(\beta\epsilon)) and s2∼𝖫𝖺𝗉​(1/((1−β)​ϵ))similar-tosubscript𝑠2𝖫𝖺𝗉11𝛽italic-ϵs_{2}\sim\mathsf{Lap}(1/((1-\beta)\epsilon)), and report localPk′:=⟨𝐮,y⟩+s1assignsuperscriptsubscriptlocalP𝑘′𝐮𝑦subscript𝑠1\text{localP}_{k}^{\prime}:=\langle\mathbf{u},y\rangle+s_{1}, localSumk′:=⟨𝐮′,y⟩+‖𝐮′‖∞⋅s1+⟨𝐯′,y⟩+‖𝐯′‖∞⋅s2assignsuperscriptsubscriptlocalSum𝑘′superscript𝐮′𝑦⋅subscriptnormsuperscript𝐮′subscript𝑠1superscript𝐯′𝑦⋅subscriptnormsuperscript𝐯′subscript𝑠2\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime}:=\langle\mathbf{u}^{\prime},y\rangle+\|\mathbf{u}^{\prime}\|_{\infty}\cdot s_{1}+\langle\mathbf{v}^{\prime},y\rangle+\|\mathbf{v}^{\prime}\|_{\infty}\cdot s_{2}.

We can tune the parameter β𝛽\beta to achieve small standard deviation of estimated AUC. However, the server may need additional validation data to select a optimal β𝛽\beta which performs the best. Sometimes, it is impractical in the setting of FL. We now show how to adaptively choose the allocation parameter β𝛽\beta for each client. Simply, we use the heuristic of choosing β𝛽\beta that minimizes the variance of localSumk′superscriptsubscriptlocalSum𝑘′\text{localSum}_{k}^{\prime} for client k𝑘k, which is equivalent to minimizing the variance of ‖𝐮′‖∞⋅s1+‖𝐯′‖∞⋅s2⋅subscriptnormsuperscript𝐮′subscript𝑠1⋅subscriptnormsuperscript𝐯′subscript𝑠2\|\mathbf{u}^{\prime}\|_{\infty}\cdot s_{1}+\|\mathbf{v}^{\prime}\|_{\infty}\cdot s_{2}.

6 Experiments

In this section, we show the experimental results of evaluating our proposed approaches.

6.1 Experimental Setup

Dataset. We evaluate the proposed approaches on Criteo 555https://www.kaggle.com/c/criteo-display-ad-challenge/data, which is a large-scale industrial binary classification dataset (with with approximately 454545 million user click records) for conversion prediction tasks. We computed the AUC on the test set which contains M=458,407𝑀458407M=458,407 where P=117,317𝑃117317P=117,317 and N=341,090𝑁341090N=341,090 for 333 epochs.

Model. We modified a popular deep learning model architecture WDL [5] for online advertising. Note that our goal is not to train the model that can beat the state-of-the-art, but to test the effectiveness of our proposed federated AUC computation approach.

Ground-truth AUC. We compare our proposed FedAUC with two AUC computation libraries (their computed results work as ground-truth and have no privacy guarantee): 1) scikit-learn666https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.metrics.auc.html; 2) Tensorflow 777https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/keras/metrics/AUC. Both approximate the AUC (Area under the curve) of the ROC. In our experiments, we set num_thresholds=1,000num_thresholds1000\text{num\_thresholds}=1,000 for Tensorflow. We use the default values for other parameters.

Evaluation Metric. For each method, we run the same setting for 100100100 times (change the random seed every time) and use the corresponding standard deviation of the computed AUC as our evaluation metric888We only include the standard deviation of computed AUCs rather than the mean because we find that the mean of our AUCs is close to the ground-truth AUC. See the results of mean AUC in Table 5 and  6 in the Appendix.. A good computation method should achieve a small std of the computed AUC.

6.2 Experimental Results

6.2.1 Results of FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}

Effectiveness of FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}. We report the standard deviation of the AUC estimated by FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}} with different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in Table  1. We put more detailed results in Table  5 and  7 in the Appendix. We can observe that vanilla FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}} (with ϵ=+∞italic-ϵ\epsilon=+\infty and ρ+=ρ−=0subscript𝜌subscript𝜌0\rho_{+}=\rho_{-}=0) which has no DP guarantee can achieve almost the same value as the ones computed by scikit-learn and Tensorflow. The corresponding results demonstrated the correctness and effectiveness of FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}. Results in Table  3 in the Appendix shows the results without debiasing as we described in Section  4.3, which demonstrates that converting the noisy AUC to the clean AUC is badly needed.

Impact of data size. We also tested the effectiveness of FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}} on a larger evaluation set which has 4,584,062 data samples which is 10 times larger than the small one. The detailed statistics of these two dataset can be seen in Table  4 in the Appendix. As shown in Table  6 (in the Appendix) and Figure  1 (a), the AUC on the large dataset is approximately 1/101101/\sqrt{10} of the value achieved on the small dataset with the same privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. It indicates that increasing the dataset size can reduce the standard deviation of the estimated AUC. The same conclusion is applicable to FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}} too.

6.2.2 Results of FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}

Both Gaussian and Laplace mechanism can be use in FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}. In our experiments, we adopt Laplace mechanism as an example to show the effectiveness of our proposed technique. We refer this technique as LocalLaplace. We also add a comparison partner GocalLaplace here. All clients use M−1𝑀1M-1 as the sensitivity when adding noise to their local statistics localSum. Given a privacy budget ϵl​o​c​a​l​S​u​msubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑆𝑢𝑚\epsilon_{localSum}, client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} draws the random noise from L​a​p​((M−1)/ϵl​o​c​a​l​S​u​m)𝐿𝑎𝑝𝑀1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑆𝑢𝑚Lap((M-1)/\epsilon_{localSum}). Each client adds the same amount of noise to its localSum. ϵl​o​c​a​l​Psubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑃\epsilon_{localP} is kept the same as LocalLaplace.

Unlike FedAUCRRsubscriptFedAUCRR\text{FedAUC}_{\text{RR}}, FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}} is sensitive to the number of clients and number of samples per client has. Based on the setting of how to assign data sample to clients, we provide two simulations to conduct the corresponding experiments.

  1. 1.

    IID: all data points are uniformly assigned to the clients.

  2. 2.

    Non-IID: all data points are assigned to the clients based on their corresponding prediction scores. Data samples with similar prediction scores will be assigned to the same client.

We divide M𝑀M data samples into K𝐾K clients based on the IID and Non-IID settings and each client has MK𝑀𝐾\frac{M}{K} data samples on average. We also provide an extreme scenario to simply our analysis: each client only has one data sample (M=K𝑀𝐾M=K). Under this setting and suppose we use accurate P𝑃P and N𝑁N to compute the AUC, we can conclude from Equation 8 and 9 (both in the Appendix) that: AUCglobalLaplaceAUClocalLaplace≈3subscriptAUCglobalLaplacesubscriptAUClocalLaplace3\frac{\text{AUC}_{\text{globalLaplace}}}{\text{AUC}_{\text{localLaplace}}}\approx\sqrt{3}. Our results as shown in Table  2 (in the Appendix) verified this observation.

Sensitivity of α𝛼\alpha. We conduct experiments to check the sensitivity of α𝛼\alpha for FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}. Given a total DP budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, ϵl​o​c​a​l​S​u​m=α​ϵsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑆𝑢𝑚𝛼italic-ϵ\epsilon_{localSum}=\alpha\epsilon and ϵl​o​c​a​l​P=(1−α​ϵ)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙𝑃1𝛼italic-ϵ\epsilon_{localP}=(1-\alpha\epsilon). We assign the data samples uniformly to 1,00010001,000 clients (IID setting) and on average each client has 458 data samples. The corresponding results are shown in Figure  1 (b). It shows that when α∈[0.5,0.6]𝛼0.50.6\alpha\in[0.5,0.6], the corresponding standard deviation of AUC estimation is the smallest. Hence, for the following experiments, we set α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5. Other settings (i.e. Non-IID and different number of clients) share the same pattern. To save space, we put the corresponding results in the Appendix as shown in Figure  4 and  5.

Advantages of Adaptive Allocation. We conduct some experiments to show the advantages of orthogonalization and corresponding adaptive allocation. Given the total DP budget ϵ=1italic-ϵ1\epsilon=1, we assign 1,00010001,000 Non-IID samples to each client. We compared another approach which only does orthogonalization (without adaptive allocation). We tune the corresponding allocation parameter β𝛽\beta and let each client share the same β𝛽\beta. The corresponding result is shown in Figure  1 (c) with legend "Orthogonal". It can achieve a smaller standard deviation than the naive one (tuning α𝛼\alpha for FedAUCLapsubscriptFedAUCLap\text{FedAUC}_{\text{Lap}}). The legend "Adaptive" in in Figure  1 (c) represents that each client adaptive allocates the DP budget and hence it should be a point in the figure. To make a better comparison with "Naive" and "Orthogonal", we show a horizontal line in the figure for "Adaptive" instead. Adaptive allocation can achieve the smallest standard deviation of AUC, which demonstrates the effectiveness of adaptive allocation. Similar results on the IID setting can be seen in the Figure  6. The distribution of the adaptive allocated parameter β𝛽\beta for all clients can be seen in Figure  8 in the Appendix.

RR vs. GlobalLaplace vs. LocalLaplace (w/wo. adaptive allocation). We now compare our proposed methods (RR, GlobalLaplace, and LocalLaplace (w/wo adaptive allocation)) in Table 7 with different settings (i.e. different number of clients and different privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon). We set the DP budget allocation parameter α=0.5𝛼0.5\alpha=0.5 for LocalLaplace without adaptive allocation. It shows that RR can gain some advantages when the avg. ##\# data samples per client is small. However, with increasing avg. ##\# data samples per client, LocalLaplace can achieve smaller standard deviation of AUC estimation since it adds smaller amounts of noise than RR and GlobalLaplace. LocalLaplace with adaptive allocation can perform the best under most of the cases.

7 Related Work

Federated Learning. FL [19, 30] can be mainly classified into three categories: horizontal FL, vFL, and federated transfer learning  [30]. When the jointly trained model is a neural network, the setting is the same as split learning such as SplitNN  [28].

Information Leakage in vFL. Recently, studies show that in vFL, even though the raw data (feature and label) is not shared, sensitive information can still be leaked from the gradients and intermediate embeddings communicated between parties. For example, [27] and [26] showed that server’s raw features can be leaked from the forward cut layer embedding. In addition, [17] studied the label leakage problem but the leakage source was the backward gradients rather than forward embeddings.

Information Protection in vFL. There are three main categories of information protection techniques in vFL: 1) cryptographic methods such as secure multi-party computation [3]; 2) system-based methods including trusted execution environments [25]; and 3) perturbation methods that add noise to the communicated messages [1, 20, 8, 6, 32]. In this paper, we focus on adding DP noise to protect the private label information during computing AUC.

8 Conclusion

We propose two label DP algorithms to compute AUC when evaluating models in vFL protocol. Through experiments, we find our algorithms can estimate AUCs accurately. We primarily focus on the online advertising scenario when the predicted scores are not considered as sensitive, and we leave the generalization to other scenarios for future work. We hope our work can bring more attention to the current vFL literature on how to protect privacy when evaluating models.

Appendix H Computing AUC from a probabilistic perspective

In a binary classification problem, given a threshold θ𝜃\theta, a predicted score sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} is predicted to be 111 if si≥θsubscript𝑠𝑖𝜃s_{i}\geq\theta. Given the ground-truth label and the predicted label (at a given threshold θ𝜃\theta), we can quantify the accuracy of the classifier on the dataset with True positives (TP(θ𝜃\theta)), False positives (FP(θ𝜃\theta)), False negatives (FN(θ𝜃\theta)), and True negatives (TN(θ𝜃\theta)). Area under the Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves plots two variables: True Positive Rate (TPR) False Positive Rate (FPR). TPR (i.e. recall) is defined as T​P​R​(θ)=T​P​(θ)T​P​(θ)+F​N​(θ)𝑇𝑃𝑅𝜃𝑇𝑃𝜃𝑇𝑃𝜃𝐹𝑁𝜃TPR(\theta)=\frac{TP(\theta)}{TP(\theta)+FN(\theta)}. False Positive Rate (FPR) is defined as (θ)=F​P​(θ)F​P​(θ)+T​N​(θ)𝜃𝐹𝑃𝜃𝐹𝑃𝜃𝑇𝑁𝜃(\theta)=\frac{FP(\theta)}{FP(\theta)+TN(\theta)}.

  • •

    True positives, TP(θ𝜃\theta), are the data points in test whose true label and predicted label equals 111. i.e. yi=1subscript𝑦𝑖1y_{i}=1 and si≥θsubscript𝑠𝑖𝜃s_{i}\geq\theta

  • •

    False positives, FP(θ𝜃\theta), are the data points in test whose true label is 00 but the predicted label is 111. i.e. yi=0subscript𝑦𝑖0y_{i}=0 and si≥θsubscript𝑠𝑖𝜃s_{i}\geq\theta.

  • •

    False negatives, FN(θ𝜃\theta), are data points whose true label is 111 but the predicted label is 00. i.e. yi=1subscript𝑦𝑖1y_{i}=1 and si<θsubscript𝑠𝑖𝜃s_{i}<\theta.

  • •

    True negatives, TN(θ𝜃\theta), are data points whose true label is 00 and the predicted label is 00. i.e. yi=0subscript𝑦𝑖0y_{i}=0 and si<θsubscript𝑠𝑖𝜃s_{i}<\theta.

The ROC curve is defined by plotting pairs of FPR(θ𝜃\theta) (x-axis) versus TPR(θ𝜃\theta) (y-axis) over all possible thresholds θ𝜃\theta. ROC curve starts at (0,0)00(0,0) and ends at (1,1)11(1,1). The area under the ROC curve (AUC) is used to evaluate the performance of a binary classifier. If the classifier is good, the ROC curve will be close to the left and upper boundary and AUC will be close to 1.01.01.0. On the other hand, if the classifier is poor, the ROC curve will be close to line from (0,0)00(0,0) to (1,1)11(1,1) with AUC around 0.50.50.5.

H.1 Computing AUC with Time Complexity O(PN)

Area under ROC curve (AUC) is well studied in statistics and is equivalent to Mann-Whitney U statistics  [22, 4]. We focus on computing the AUC by viewing it as the probability of correct ranking of a random positive-negative pair. Suppose we have M𝑀M samples including P𝑃P positives and N𝑁N negatives, where M=P+N𝑀𝑃𝑁M=P+N. Given a classifier ℱℱ\mathcal{F}, it gives a prediction score sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} for each sample i∈[1,M]𝑖1𝑀i\in[1,M]. We then have M​N𝑀𝑁MN positive-negative pairs with score <si,sj><s_{i},s_{j}> (i∈[1,M]𝑖1𝑀i\in[1,M] and j∈[1,N]𝑗1𝑁j\in[1,N]) where sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} and sjsubscript𝑠𝑗s_{j} are prediction scores of positive sample i𝑖i and negative sample j𝑗j respectively. Then AUC of classifier ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is:

AUC=I(<si,sj>)M​N,i∈[1,M]andj∈[1,N]\text{AUC}=\frac{I(<s_{i},s_{j}>)}{MN},i\in[1,M]\quad\text{and}\quad j\in[1,N] (5)

where

I(<si,sj>)={1,ifsi>sj,0,o​t​h​e​r​w​i​s​e.I(<s_{i},s_{j}>)=\begin{cases}1,\text{if}\quad s_{i}>s_{j},\\ 0,otherwise.\end{cases}

The time complexity of computing AUC is O​(P​N)𝑂𝑃𝑁O(PN).

H.2 Computing AUC with Time Complexity O​(M​log⁡M)𝑂𝑀𝑀O(M\log M)

We firstly rank all instances based on their prediction scores in an increasing order. Each score sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} (i∈[1,M]𝑖1𝑀i\in[1,M]) will be assigned a ranking risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}. The instance with the highest order will be assigned r=M−1𝑟𝑀1r=M-1, and the second highest one will be assigned M−2𝑀2M-2 and so on. The smallest ranking score is r=0𝑟0r=0.

Then AUC can be computed as:

AUC=∑i=1Mri⋅yi−P​(P−1)2P​NAUCsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑀⋅subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑃𝑃12𝑃𝑁\text{AUC}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{M}r_{i}\cdot y_{i}-\frac{P(P-1)}{2}}{PN} (6)

where yi∈{0,1}subscript𝑦𝑖01y_{i}\in\{0,1\} is the ground-truth label for instance i𝑖i (with ranking score risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}). The time complexity of this method is O​(M​log⁡M)𝑂𝑀𝑀O(M\log M).

Appendix P Estimate π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}

Suppose we observe M¯¯𝑀\bar{M} positive examples and N¯¯𝑁\bar{N} negative examples in the corrupted data D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}. We have:

P′+N′=P¯+N¯,P′​(1−ρ+)+N​ρ−=P¯formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑃′superscript𝑁′¯𝑃¯𝑁superscript𝑃′1subscript𝜌𝑁subscript𝜌¯𝑃P^{\prime}+N^{\prime}=\bar{P}+\bar{N},\quad P^{\prime}(1-\rho_{+})+N\rho_{-}=\bar{P} (10)

where P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} and N′superscript𝑁′N^{\prime} are estimated positive and negative numbers in the clean data D𝐷D.

We then obtain:

P′=P¯​(1−ρ−)−N¯​ρ−1−ρ+−ρ−,N′=P¯+N¯−P′formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑃′¯𝑃1subscript𝜌¯𝑁subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌subscript𝜌superscript𝑁′¯𝑃¯𝑁superscript𝑃′P^{\prime}=\frac{\bar{P}(1-\rho_{-})-\bar{N}\rho_{-}}{1-\rho_{+}-\rho_{-}},\quad N^{\prime}=\bar{P}+\bar{N}-P^{\prime} (11)

Then we use P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} and N′superscript𝑁′N^{\prime} to estimate base rate π𝜋\pi as π′superscript𝜋′\pi^{\prime}:

π′=P′P′+N′superscript𝜋′superscript𝑃′superscript𝑃′superscript𝑁′\pi^{\prime}=\frac{P^{\prime}}{P^{\prime}+N^{\prime}} (12)

Appendix R Privacy Analysis of Prediction Scores

In this section, we talk about how clients know the ranking results of their prediction scores and the corresponding privacy issue.

In the vanilla setting, each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} can send its shuffled prediction scores sksuperscript𝑠𝑘s^{k} to the server. The server then aggregates all the prediction scores and sort them in an increasing order. Each prediction score siksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑘s_{i}^{k} (i∈[1,M]𝑖1𝑀i\in[1,M]) will be assigned a ranking order riksuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘r_{i}^{k}. The instance with the highest order will be assigned r=M−1𝑟𝑀1r=M-1, and the second highest one will be assigned M−2𝑀2M-2 and so on. The smallest ranking score is r=0𝑟0r=0. The server sends each ranking order riksuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑘r_{i}^{k} back to the corresponding client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} which owns siksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑘s_{i}^{k}. It’s worth mentioning the prediction scores have to be shared with the server for some tasks. For example, the clients have to report the predicted conversion rate (CVR) of the ad impression to the server in online advertisements. The server 121212ad exchange can later on calculate the bid price by multiplying the predicted CVR with a constant parameter tuned according to the campaign budget and performance  [23]. Then the server can select the advertiser who proposed the highest bid price as the winner to show the ad.

Interested readers maybe curious is it possible to infer the label information based on the prediction scores. Here we propose a simple attack method by selecting the samples with top-K prediction scores as positive labels. We measure the corresponding guessing performance by precision and recall. As shown in Figure  7 and Table  8, positive instances can have a relative higher prediction scores than negative ones at some density areas. For example, we can achieve a 79%percent7979\% precision if we select the instances with top-100100100 prediction scores. However, since the prediction scores sksuperscript𝑠𝑘s^{k} are shuffled before sending to the server so that the server has no idea which prediction score belongs to which data sample 131313|sk|≥2superscript𝑠𝑘2|s^{k}|\geq 2.

Instead of the vanilla setting, we also propose some alternative solutions to achieve the sorting goal. We may leverage DP to add noise to the prediction scores. Since the prediction score is the output of a softmax/sigmoid function, the corresponding sensitivity Δ=1Δ1\Delta=1. We can then leverage Gaussian or Laplace mechanism to add noise to the prediction scores. The corresponding results can be seen in Table  9. We can observe that the utility of the computed AUC is highly sensitive to the privacy budget. We cannot achieve a reasonable AUC utility with a small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon (i.e. ϵ≤10italic-ϵ10\epsilon\leq 10).

To achieve both privacy and utility, we can leverage secure multi-party computation (MPC) technique  [15, 13] to achieve the sorting goal. For example, Hamada et al.  [13] constructed a quicksort protocol from the quicksort algorithm with their MPC sorting protocol. The resultant protocol can sort 323232-bit words and 1,000,00010000001,000,000 secret-shared values in 1,22712271,227 seconds, while existing sorting protocols cannot sort within 3,60036003,600 seconds.

In this paper, we adopt the vanilla setting to describe our AUC computation technique by default, since the prediction scores are shared between the server and clients. MPC based sorting protocol can replace our vanilla sorting method if necessary (privacy of prediction scores is a concern).

The distribution of local β𝛽\beta is shown in Figure  8.

Appendix T Computation resources

We conduct our experiments over a Macbook Pro with 2.4 GHz 8-Core Intel Core i9 and 64 GB 2667 MHz DDR4. Each epoch of run of Criteo takes about 2.5 minutes.
